topics.title: Correlation & Relationships

concepts.title: Covariance
concepts.definition: Measure of how two variables vary together; sign indicates direction of joint movement.
concepts.plain_english: Do they move together up/down?
concepts.when_to_use: Use as a building block for correlation and multivariate stats.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Covariance.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Pearson Correlation
concepts.definition: Correlation measuring linear association between two continuous variables (−1 to 1).
concepts.plain_english: How strongly two numbers move together in a straight-line way.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for linear relationships with roughly normal data and few outliers.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Variables are measured appropriately.; For Pearson: relationship is roughly linear.
concepts.limitations: Correlation does not imply causation.; Outliers can strongly affect correlation.

formulas.label: Pearson r
formulas.explanation: Linear association between two numeric variables.

examples.title: Pearson Correlation micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Pearson Correlation.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Spearman Correlation
concepts.definition: Rank-based correlation measuring monotonic association; robust to nonlinearity and outliers.
concepts.plain_english: Whether one tends to increase when the other increases (not necessarily linearly).
concepts.when_to_use: Use for ordinal data or non-normal relationships.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Variables are measured appropriately.; For Pearson: relationship is roughly linear.
concepts.limitations: Correlation does not imply causation.; Outliers can strongly affect correlation.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Spearman Correlation.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Kendall’s Tau
concepts.definition: Rank correlation based on concordant/discordant pairs; robust for small samples and ties.
concepts.plain_english: A stable way to compare ranked relationships.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for ordinal data with ties or small n.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Kendall’s Tau.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Correlation vs Causation
concepts.definition: Correlation indicates association, not necessarily cause; confounding and reverse causality can mislead.
concepts.plain_english: Two things moving together doesn’t prove one causes the other.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to avoid incorrect causal claims from observational data.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Variables are measured appropriately.; For Pearson: relationship is roughly linear.
concepts.limitations: Correlation does not imply causation.; Outliers can strongly affect correlation.

examples.title: Correlation vs Causation micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Correlation vs Causation.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Multicollinearity
concepts.definition: High correlation among predictors that inflates uncertainty in regression coefficient estimates.
concepts.plain_english: Predictors overlap, making it hard to tell who drives what.
concepts.when_to_use: Use VIF/diagnostics to decide feature selection or regularization.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this diagnostic to confirm model/process assumptions.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ignoring diagnostics leads to biased conclusions

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Multicollinearity.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Partial Correlation
concepts.definition: Correlation between two variables after controlling for one or more other variables.
concepts.plain_english: Relationship between A and B after accounting for C.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to reduce confounding in exploratory analysis.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.limitations: Correlation does not imply causation.; Outliers can strongly affect correlation.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Partial Correlation.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

topics.description: Quantify how variables move together and avoid common traps like correlation vs causation.

topics.title: Regression

concepts.title: Simple Linear Regression
concepts.definition: Model predicting a continuous outcome using one predictor with a linear relationship.
concepts.plain_english: A straight-line model for prediction.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to estimate and predict with one main driver.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Good performance on training data can be misleading
Predictive accuracy does not imply causality

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Relationship is approximately linear.; Errors are independent.; Residual variance is roughly constant (homoscedastic).
concepts.limitations: Collinearity can destabilize coefficients.; Outliers/high leverage points can distort estimates.

links.note: Often learned alongside Multiple Linear Regression.
Often learned alongside R² and Adjusted R².

formulas.label: Regression line
formulas.explanation: Predicted outcome as a linear function of x.

examples.scenario: You want to predict y from x and understand how y changes as x increases.
examples.solution: Fit the model; interpret coefficients and diagnostics; use results to identify improvement levers and validate impact.

concepts.title: Multiple Linear Regression
concepts.definition: Linear model using multiple predictors to explain/predict a continuous outcome.
concepts.plain_english: A straight-line model with multiple drivers.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when outcomes depend on several factors.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Good performance on training data can be misleading
Predictive accuracy does not imply causality

concepts.limitations: Collinearity can destabilize coefficients.; Outliers/high leverage points can distort estimates.

concepts.title: Regression Assumptions
concepts.definition: Key assumptions include linearity, independent errors, constant variance, and approximately normal residuals for inference.
concepts.plain_english: Rules that must mostly hold for trustworthy coefficients and p-values.
concepts.when_to_use: Use before trusting regression inference and intervals.
concepts.improvement_goal: Verify this assumption before trusting results.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: If assumptions fail, conclusions may be wrong

concepts.assumptions: Relationship is approximately linear.; Errors are independent.; Residual variance is roughly constant (homoscedastic).

concepts.title: R² and Adjusted R²
concepts.definition: R² is the fraction of outcome variance explained; adjusted R² penalizes unnecessary predictors.
concepts.plain_english: How much your model explains (with a penalty for extra variables).
concepts.when_to_use: Use to compare models (with validation) and explainability.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

concepts.title: Residual Analysis
concepts.definition: Examining residuals to check patterns, bias, nonlinearity, and assumption violations.
concepts.plain_english: Look at what the model gets wrong.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to improve model specification and trustworthiness.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this diagnostic to confirm model/process assumptions.

concepts.title: Heteroscedasticity
concepts.definition: Non-constant residual variance across fitted values or predictors, affecting standard errors.
concepts.plain_english: Errors spread more for some values than others.
concepts.when_to_use: Use robust SEs, transformations, or re-specify the model if present.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this diagnostic to confirm model/process assumptions.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ignoring diagnostics leads to biased conclusions

concepts.title: Autocorrelation
concepts.definition: Correlation of residuals over time/order, violating independence and biasing inference.
concepts.plain_english: Errors are related across time steps.
concepts.when_to_use: Use time-series methods or add lag terms if present.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this diagnostic to confirm model/process assumptions.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ignoring diagnostics leads to biased conclusions

concepts.title: Polynomial Regression
concepts.definition: Regression using polynomial terms to model curved relationships.
concepts.plain_english: A curved line model.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when relationship is nonlinear but smooth.

concepts.title: Interaction Terms
concepts.definition: Terms that allow the effect of one predictor to depend on another predictor.
concepts.plain_english: One factor changes how another factor matters.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when effects differ across subgroups or conditions.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.

concepts.plain_english: Turn categories into 0/1 columns.

concepts.title: Coefficient Interpretation
concepts.definition: Interpreting coefficients as expected change in outcome per unit change in predictor (holding others constant).
concepts.plain_english: What each driver means in the model.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to translate models into business/clinical insight.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?

concepts.title: CI for Coefficients
concepts.definition: Confidence intervals for coefficients quantify uncertainty around estimated effects.
concepts.plain_english: A plausible range for each driver’s impact.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to judge stability and practical significance of coefficients.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.

concepts.title: Hypothesis Tests for Betas
concepts.definition: Tests whether each coefficient differs from zero (or another value) using t-statistics and p-values.
concepts.plain_english: Checks if a driver likely matters beyond noise.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to screen drivers (with caution about multiple testing).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance
Multiple testing inflates false positives

concepts.title: Ridge Regression
concepts.definition: Regression with L2 penalty that shrinks coefficients to reduce overfitting and handle collinearity.
concepts.plain_english: A model that reduces overreaction to noisy predictors.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when many correlated predictors exist.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Good performance on training data can be misleading
Predictive accuracy does not imply causality

concepts.title: Lasso Regression
concepts.definition: Regression with L1 penalty that can set some coefficients to zero (feature selection).
concepts.plain_english: A model that can drop unnecessary predictors.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for sparse models and feature selection.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?

concepts.title: Elastic Net
concepts.definition: Regularization combining L1 and L2 penalties, balancing shrinkage and selection.
concepts.plain_english: Mixes ridge and lasso benefits.
concepts.when_to_use: Use with many correlated features and desire for sparsity.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?

concepts.title: Log Transformation
concepts.definition: Applying log to reduce skew, stabilize variance, and linearize multiplicative relationships.
concepts.plain_english: Compresses big values and tames long tails.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when data are right-skewed or variance grows with the mean.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.

concepts.title: Box-Cox Transformation
concepts.definition: Family of power transforms chosen to improve normality/variance stability.
concepts.plain_english: A smart transformation chooser for skewed data.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when you need a transformation and want a data-driven choice.

topics.title: Advanced Methods

concepts.title: Logistic Regression
concepts.definition: Classification model predicting probability of a binary outcome using a logistic link function.
concepts.plain_english: Predicts yes/no probability.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for binary outcomes like readmission (yes/no), defect (yes/no).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Good performance on training data can be misleading
Predictive accuracy does not imply causality

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Observations are independent.; Log-odds are approximately linear in predictors.
concepts.limitations: Class imbalance can mislead accuracy metrics.; Interpret coefficients carefully using odds ratios and context.

links.note: Often learned alongside Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE).
Often learned alongside Generalized Linear Models (GLM).

formulas.label: Logistic model
formulas.explanation: Models log-odds as a linear function.

examples.scenario: You want to predict y from x and understand how y changes as x increases.
examples.solution: Fit the model; interpret coefficients and diagnostics; use results to identify improvement levers and validate impact.

concepts.title: Odds Ratios
concepts.definition: Ratio of odds; in logistic regression, exp(coef) is the odds ratio for a 1-unit predictor change.
concepts.plain_english: How much the odds change when a driver changes.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to interpret logistic regression effects.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

concepts.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE)
concepts.definition: Parameter estimation method choosing values that maximize the likelihood of observed data under a model.
concepts.plain_english: Finds the parameters that make the data most plausible.
concepts.when_to_use: Use in many models (GLM, logistic regression) and distribution fitting.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Inconsistent procedures cause inconsistent results

concepts.title: Generalized Linear Models (GLM)
concepts.definition: Extension of linear regression allowing non-normal outcomes via link functions (e.g., logistic, Poisson).
concepts.plain_english: Linear models for many outcome types.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for counts, proportions, and other non-normal outcomes.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

Predictive accuracy does not imply causality

concepts.title: Nonparametric Tests
concepts.definition: Tests that rely less on distributional assumptions, often using ranks.
concepts.plain_english: Tests that work even when data aren’t normal.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when normality/variance assumptions fail or for ordinal data.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance
Multiple testing inflates false positives

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Bootstrapping
concepts.definition: Resampling method to estimate uncertainty by repeatedly sampling with replacement from the observed data.
concepts.plain_english: Simulates many 'new samples' from your data.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for confidence intervals when formulas are hard or assumptions are weak.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Inconsistent procedures cause inconsistent results

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.

concepts.title: Permutation Tests
concepts.definition: Tests significance by comparing the observed statistic to values obtained by randomly permuting labels.
concepts.plain_english: Checks how unusual your result is under 'no effect' by shuffling.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when assumptions are unclear and you can shuffle labels.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance
Multiple testing inflates false positives

concepts.title: Bayesian Statistics (Intro)
concepts.definition: Framework that updates prior beliefs with data to produce a posterior distribution.
concepts.plain_english: Start with a belief, then update it with evidence.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when you want probabilistic statements and to incorporate prior knowledge.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE).

concepts.title: Prior / Posterior / Likelihood
concepts.definition: Prior encodes beliefs before data; likelihood measures data fit; posterior combines them via Bayes’ rule.
concepts.plain_english: Before-data belief + evidence = after-data belief.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to interpret Bayesian outputs clearly.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

concepts.title: Quantile Regression
concepts.definition: Regression modeling conditional quantiles (e.g., median, 90th percentile) instead of the mean.
concepts.plain_english: Predicts the median or p90, not the average.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for tail-focused goals (reduce p90 wait time).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Good performance on training data can be misleading
Predictive accuracy does not imply causality

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Relationship is approximately linear.; Errors are independent.; Residual variance is roughly constant (homoscedastic).
concepts.limitations: Collinearity can destabilize coefficients.; Outliers/high leverage points can distort estimates.

links.note: Often learned alongside Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE).

examples.title: Quantile Regression example
examples.scenario: You want to predict y from x and understand how y changes as x increases.
examples.solution: Fit the model; interpret coefficients and diagnostics; use results to identify improvement levers and validate impact.

concepts.title: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
concepts.definition: Dimensionality reduction that transforms correlated variables into uncorrelated components capturing most variance.
concepts.plain_english: Compresses many correlated features into a few summary features.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for visualization, noise reduction, and multicollinearity handling.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?

concepts.title: K-means Clustering
concepts.definition: Unsupervised method that partitions data into k clusters by minimizing within-cluster distances.
concepts.plain_english: Groups similar rows together automatically.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to segment populations or identify patterns without labels.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this model to predict outcomes and understand drivers.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?

concepts.title: Silhouette Score
concepts.definition: Metric assessing clustering quality based on separation between clusters and cohesion within clusters.
concepts.plain_english: How well your clusters are separated and consistent.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to evaluate and choose number of clusters.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
